thread.title: Cake decorator sees headcount fall by 36 amid year of cost cutting

author: Jonathon Manning
title: Cake decorator sees headcount fall by 36 amid year of cost cutting
text:

The number of staff employed at award-winning cake decorating business Culpitt Limited fell by nearly a quarter last year as the firm carried out a major cost cutting exercise. 
Culpitt saw its workforce fall from 156 members of staff to just 120 during the 2016 calendar year. 
The biggest fall in headcount was in the firm’s management and administration team, which saw its numbers drop from 60 to 25. 
The Ashington-headquartered business said it had been focusing on reducing costs over the year. 
In the company accounts, finance director Simon Keogh said: “Steps were taken during 2016 to reduce overhead costs and focus on profitable baskets. By maintaining the core competencies of the business there is every reason to believe that the company can build on the foundations established.” 
The cost cutting plans were put in place after a restructuring exercise saw Culpitt fully take over the running of its subsidiary business, Eileen Grace Limited. 
As part of the restructure, Eileen Grace ceased trading in September 2015 and all 14 of the firm’s staff were transferred to Culpitt in November. 
Despite the cost cutting, Culpitt made a loss of £302,000 for 2016, after previously reporting an operating profit of £1m during the previous year. However, turnover at the firm grew by 6.4% to £18.2m. 
The lion’s share of the growth came from its UK sales, which increased from £14m to £15m. Mainland Europe sales fell slightly from £2.71m to £2.68m. Read More Four North East firms scoop Queen’s Awards for Enterprise 
Culpitt said that Brexit had a “significant” impact on its financial performance, with the falling value of the pound increasing purchasing costs. 
Mr Keogh added: “Trading conditions in the UK and worldwide remained challenging during the year, the Eileen Grace business was incorporated into Culpitt and growth was seen through export and supermarket channels. 
“The company continues to offer innovative products and an industry leading delivery and service proposition and despite the ongoing challenging economic conditions the company has continued to meet the changing needs of its customer base.” 
The biggest impact to the company’s balance sheet were increased administration costs, which soared by over £1m to £1.9m. 
In both 2012 and 2016 Culpitt received the Queen’s Award for Enterprise. Last year it won the award for outstanding growth in international sales over the last three years. Like us on Facebook
